Sonny.Action: Takes the florist box from Jackie, who is uncertain and waits for directions from Sonny.
Checks watch and calmly coordinates timing with Sal, showing control and consideration.
Takes charge by directing Jackie and coordinating timing with Sal, checks watch and signals '30 seconds, Sal...'
Moves confidently into the bank carrying the florist box and begins filling out a deposit slip, showing calmness and preparation.
Relies on Jackie who is uncertain and waits for directions, indicating delegation but also possible overreliance on less capable accomplices.
Dismisses Jackie's concerns and tells her to stay away, showing irritation and lack of openness.
Takes a deep breath and prepares to take control of the situation, showing focus but little emotional connection.
Aims a rifle at Sylvia, causing her to fear for her safety.
Dismisses Jackie's concerns and insists on continuing the plan despite bad vibes, showing determination but possibly poor judgment.
Observes the bank closing and locking, then strategically moves to the teller's cage area and arms himself with a rifle, demonstrating situational awareness and preparation.
Yells at Jackie to stay and insults him when he tries to leave.
Allows Howard to be let out of the bank despite the stickup.
Frisks Howard and then locks the door again after letting him out.
Tells Jackie not to take the car but offers a practical alternative (subway) and insists on needing the car for their plan.
Reassures Jackie about the person under the desk by saying 'It's okay... it's okay...'
Speaks gently to Jenny under the desk, telling her 'Nobody's gonna hurt you.'
Orders Howard to lock the door and pull the drapes firmly and repeatedly, showing impatience or frustration.
Takes control by grabbing keys from Howard and locking the door again, showing initiative and leadership.
Insists on keeping the car for their use, showing foresight about their needs.
Responds calmly to Jackieâ€™s report about someone under the desk and approaches the situation carefully, showing situational awareness.
Commands Howard to pull the drapes to limit outside visibility, demonstrating tactical thinking.
Repeats the order to Howard when he hesitates, showing persistence but also possible frustration or lack of immediate control.
Sprays red paint on the cameras to prevent alarms, joking with a grin 'No replay, folks... no alarms...'
Grabs Mulvaney's hand and angrily confronts him about using the wrong key that would trigger a silent alarm, almost hitting him with his fist
Sprays red paint on all three security cameras to disable visual recording and alarms.
Quickly notices that Mulvaney is about to use a key that would trigger a silent alarm and stops him, preventing a security breach.
Expresses fury but insists he doesn't want to hurt anyone, emphasizing his Catholic faith.
Notices Miriam crying and stops to look at her, showing awareness of her emotional state.
Pressures Miriam to open the safe and questions her hesitation.
Shows frustration and alarm when told there is little money, but tries to reassure Mulvaney.
Identifies the key with the silent alarm spur and insists on using the correct key, preventing a potential alarm trigger.
Reacts with alarm and frustration when discovering the safe contains very little money, showing awareness of the situation's gravity.
Shows impatience and anger towards Miriam when she hesitates, potentially undermining group cohesion.
Speaks gently to Miriam when she is terrified, reassuring her it is not her fault.
Questions why he would shoot Miriam, indicating he does not intend to harm her.
Grabs Sylvia's hands to stop her from taking all the cash, showing concern and control rather than aggression.
Pulls out a plastic bag from his pocket and hands it to Miriam to put money into it, showing preparedness.
Reacts gently to Miriam's fear, tries to calm her down, showing emotional control under pressure.
Commands others to answer the phone and opens the teller's gate, showing leadership and situational awareness.
Tries to open a locked drawer and quickly identifies the head teller to get it unlocked, showing problem-solving skills.
Grabs Sylvia's hands to stop her from taking all the cash, carefully taking all singles but one, showing attention to detail and control.
Laughs and throws decoy money in the air gaily after discovering it is marked.
Yells at Sal and Mulvaney, calling the phones 'chicken shit' and telling Sal to let Mulvaney answer the phones.
Mimics Sylvia sarcastically while they work together.
Carefully disables the automatic alarm by slipping paper under the clip and removing the single bill without triggering it.
Recognizes and exposes decoy money as marked bills, showing awareness of bank security tactics.
Takes control of the cash drawers and directs others, showing leadership and confidence.
Yells at Sal and Mulvaney to answer phones, showing frustration but also attempting to delegate tasks.
Tells Miriam to stop crying, saying 'Please... quit that. It's not necessary.'
Speaks harshly and uses profanity toward others, e.g. 'Don't get any ideas, fucker...'
Holds out the plastic bag for the traveler's checks to Miriam, showing some consideration.
Burns the register pages to cover tracks, showing pragmatic but cold behavior.
Commands Mulvaney to give him the traveler's checks and register, takes control of the situation by moving hostages and attempting to destroy evidence (burning register pages).
Shows impatience and frustration with others (e.g., yelling at Mulvaney, dismissing Sylvia's request to watch language), but maintains focus on objectives.
Fails to effectively burn the register pages, resulting in smoke but poor combustion, indicating a lack of skill in destroying evidence.
Attempts to calm Miriam by asking her to stop crying, showing some emotional control and leadership.
Demands keys from Howard to facilitate escape, showing awareness of next steps and control over the situation.
Calms Howard down, reassures him he won't hurt him, asks for keys gently.
Loses patience with the situation, approaches Howard with a rifle causing fear.
Calmly negotiates with Howard to get the keys, reassuring him not to panic and not to get hurt.
Loses patience and puts down his rifle when Howard backs away, then looks to Sal for coverage, showing situational awareness.
Moves quickly and cautiously toward the front of the bank, hiding behind posts and peeking through draperies to assess the situation outside.
Starts to run back to get his gun from Margaret's desk after spotting a man approaching, indicating quick reaction but possibly impulsive.
Rushes to put out the fire at the register to prevent further damage.
Grabs the gun and commands everyone to freeze, causing hysteria among the women.
Rushes to get the gun from the desk quickly and moves to a strategic position near Mulvaney.
Notices the smoking register and immediately acts to stamp out the fire, preventing further danger.
Grabs the gun and commands everyone to freeze, attempting to control the escalating situation.
Moves with Mulvaney to cover him and listens attentively behind blinds to protect him.
Hands Mulvaney the keys when requested, facilitating his exit.
Moves with Mulvaney to cover him while he approaches the front door, listens carefully behind blinds, and hands over the keys when demanded.
Insists Mulvaney go outside with him to avoid police trouble, showing concern for others' safety.
Orders Sal to get the hostages into the vault, ensuring their containment but also their safety.
Responds to Jenny's concern about breathing by allowing the vault gate to remain open, showing consideration for hostages' comfort.
Takes control of the situation by directing Mulvaney to answer the phone and giving clear instructions to Sal to get the hostages into the vault.
Uses Mulvaney's keys to open the vault lock, showing resourcefulness and practical skill.
Refuses to close the vault completely despite hostages' concerns about breathing, potentially risking their safety and escalating tension.
Allows Sylvia and Edna to leave the vault to use the bathroom despite the risk, showing consideration for their needs.
Uses a harsh tone with Sylvia about bathroom breaks and Maria's presence, showing impatience and suspicion.
Provides a wastebasket for the women to use in case of emergency, showing practical care and concern.
Allows Sylvia and Edna to leave the vault to use the bathroom despite the risk, showing flexibility and responsiveness to the group's needs.
Sprints to check the ladies' room and discovers Maria hidden there, preventing a potential security breach.
Expresses frustration and confusion about Maria's presence, but quickly regains control and herds the women back into the vault.
Moves slowly and quietly to take the phone, listens to the detective's warnings without reacting aggressively.
Cuts off the detective's voice on the phone almost sadly, showing restraint and a non-confrontational attitude.
Slowly takes the phone and listens to the detective, showing caution and awareness of the situation.
Cuts off the detective's call abruptly and looks uncertain, indicating hesitation and lack of confidence in handling the negotiation.
Paces anxiously, tries to figure out what to do, asks for time to think.
Threatens police with violence over the phone.
Responds with disgust and distance to a caller asking for Jenny, showing concern for others' privacy.
Admits he took too long and is visibly trying to think through the situation by pacing and asking for time to think.
Takes control of the ringing phone and issues a clear, confident threat to the police to keep away from the bank.
Shows frustration and disgust when dealing with an irrelevant phone call, holding the phone at arm's length.
Tells Jenny to tell the truth to her husband, showing trust and sincerity.
Threatens to throw bodies out the door to intimidate police, showing coldness and lack of genuine concern.
Shows tenderness and care toward frightened Jenny, treating her gently despite the situation.
Signals Jenny to hurry up and leave, showing concern for her safety.
Moves to Sal to reassure him apologetically and tenderly, expressing guilt and offering hope for a way out.
Signals Jenny to hurry up and tries to manage the situation by reassuring Sal and expressing a plan to get out of the hostage situation.
Shows some guilt and apologizes to Sal, indicating emotional awareness but also possible uncertainty.
Reassures the hostages that everything will be all right if they cooperate and urges calm to avoid anyone getting hurt.
Shows consideration for basic needs of hostages, allowing bathroom breaks and phone use.
Engages in casual conversation with Mulvaney, showing a friendly and approachable demeanor.
Calmly addresses the hostages, encourages cooperation, and tries to keep everyone calm to avoid violence.
Assigns roles to himself and Mulvaney to check other exits, showing some tactical thinking.
Questions the competence of the guard, showing some awareness of the situation's security.
Appears uncertain or dismissive about the guard's training and armament, indicating some lack of detailed knowledge.
Engages Mulvaney in conversation, acknowledges his cooperation, and shares a laugh while working together to block the door.
Warns Mulvaney not to ask questions and threatens him if he finds out who Sonny is.
Expresses concern about the danger Mulvaney would face if taken along, showing some protective awareness.
Gives Mulvaney his jacket to put on again after being pinned, showing concern for his comfort and safety.
Chooses to take a married woman with kids as hostage to protect her, indicating consideration and empathy.
Calls Mulvaney a nice guy and warns him not to fool around, showing a mix of friendliness and assertiveness.
Chooses not to take Mulvaney as a hostage, instead selecting a married woman with children to reduce the likelihood of police violence.
Gives Mulvaney his jacket to put on again, showing awareness of appearances and control over the situation.
Warns Mulvaney not to 'fuck around' with him, asserting authority and control.
Assures Moretti that the people in the bank are okay.
Admits he is not alone and identifies Sal as a killer, showing blunt honesty.
Puts all the phone receivers back on the hooks, then answers the ringing phone and communicates with Moretti, providing clear information about the situation and his confederates.
Admits uncertainty about what to do next when asked by Moretti.
Agrees to let Moretti frisk him to build trust and facilitate communication.
Responds to Moretti's request with openness and a friendly tone ('Call me whatever you want').
Refuses to give his real name, uses a nickname instead, showing evasiveness rather than straightforwardness.
Agrees to frisk Moretti to build trust and allow negotiation, showing some willingness to cooperate and strategic thinking.
Responds casually and somewhat dismissively to Moretti's requests, indicating a lack of formality or seriousness in communication.
Refuses to release women hostages initially, saying 'Women is all we got.'
Agrees to negotiate and send one hostage out alive to show good faith.
Gives keys to Sylvia to help release a hostage.
Refuses to release all hostages, stating they are what keep him alive, showing awareness of leverage.
Engages in negotiation by agreeing to release one hostage to show good faith.
Consults with his group and coordinates who will be sent out first, demonstrating leadership and communication.
Whispers instructions to Sal to show negotiation intent, indicating strategic thinking.
Moves with hostages toward the door with gun aimed, maintaining control and security.
Gives keys to Sylvia to open the door, showing practical problem-solving.
Covers Sylvia as she moves to unlock the front door for Howard, protecting her with his rifle.
Covers Sylvia as she moves to unlock the front door for Howard, maintaining a protective stance with his rifle.
Expresses concern for Sal and the girls' safety, showing protective instincts.
Distrusts Moretti's intentions, questions if he will be jumped.
Expresses concern about cops coming in too close, showing awareness of the tactical situation.
Refuses to come out immediately, citing fear for Sal and the girls' safety, showing cautiousness and protective instincts.
Questions Moretti's intentions and shows distrust, indicating a careful and skeptical mindset.
Remains in the shadows rather than stepping into the open, possibly avoiding unnecessary exposure.
Nudges Sylvia ahead of him to shield or protect her as they come into view of the media and crowd.
Faces the overwhelming situation with a blank expression, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Responds to Moretti's attempt to negotiate with sarcasm and hostility, showing distrust and aggression.
Stares blankly at Moretti's advice and responds with sarcasm and anger rather than engaging strategically.
Acknowledges the severity of his situation and the presence of overwhelming police forces, showing awareness of his predicament.
Defiantly confronts heavily armed police, demands they lower their weapons to prevent violence, and appeals to the crowd and media sincerely.
Defiantly confronts heavily armed police, commands attention, and successfully pressures them to lower their guns, gaining crowd support and media attention.
Suddenly realizing what control he has, enjoying it, turns mockingly to cameras.
Suddenly realizing what control he has, enjoying it, and mockingly turning his profile to cameras.
Holds the door open patiently for Sylvia to enter the bank.
Holds the door open patiently for Sylvia to enter the bank, showing calm and considerate behavior under pressure.
Engages cooperatively with Moretti and others, maintaining control of the situation as he re-enters the bank.
Turns to grin and wave back at the crowd applauding and screaming outside the bank.
Makes a reassuring gesture to Mulvaney to let him know Howard is safe.
Talks to Sal about the media presence, noting it looks better for them than before.
Turns to grin and wave back at crowd after they applaud and scream.
Makes reassuring gesture to Mulvaney to indicate Howard is safe.
Instructs Mulvaney to turn on the TV to monitor the situation.
Comments to Sal that media presence makes the situation look better than before.
Answers the TV newsman's questions calmly and explains his difficult situation honestly.
Shows frustration about the difficulty of finding legitimate work due to union restrictions and low pay.
Takes the phone and agrees to talk to the TV newsman, engaging in a calm and reasoned explanation of his motives.
Struggles to provide a clear or strategic justification for the robbery, showing some confusion or lack of planning in his responses.
Expresses frustration about the media's treatment and demands recognition for the danger he and others are in.
Uses aggressive and confrontational language toward the TV newsman.
Confronts the TV newsman aggressively, demanding attention and trying to leverage media coverage to his advantage.
Fails to maintain control of the interaction, becoming confrontational and somewhat erratic, which risks alienating the media.
Shows concern about the outcome of the conversation and tries to figure out what went wrong.
Attempts to negotiate a deal with the FBI to get out alive and avoid harsh charges.
Remembers and acknowledges the pact with Sal and Jackie, showing awareness of their shared situation.
Takes the phone away from Jenny to answer a threatening call, protecting her from potential harm.
Hangs up the phone abruptly after the TV transmission is cut off, showing confusion and lack of understanding of the consequences.
Seeks advice from Sal and Mulvaney, indicating willingness to collaborate and consider options.
Proposes negotiating a deal with the FBI to get out alive and avoid kidnapping charges, showing some strategic thinking.
Appears uncertain and puzzled about the situation and the outcome of his actions, indicating lack of control and confidence.
Takes initiative to answer the ringing phone quickly, preventing Jenny from answering, showing alertness and control over the situation.
Reassures the hostages that they will all get out alive and encourages cooperation.
Expresses anger and hostility toward the threatening caller.
Tries to maintain calm and optimism by focusing on a positive escape plan.
Formulates a clear escape plan involving a helicopter and a jet, tries to maintain control and calm the hostages, negotiates with the police by asking for Moretti and promising cooperation.
Reacts emotionally to the threatening phone call by slamming down the receiver and insulting the caller, which could escalate tensions.
Asks Sal about family and friends, tries to engage him in conversation about escape plans.
Realizes he is holding a gun unnecessarily and hands it to Sal.
Realizes Sal doesn't need the gun and hands it over, showing awareness and control.
Stops to consider Sal's answer about Wyoming, showing some reflection.
Steps out of the bank and commands cops to put down their weapons, demonstrating confidence and authority.
Is caught off guard and physically attacked by a man from the crowd, showing a lapse in situational awareness.
Reassures Sal by saying 'It's okay, Sal' despite Sal wanting to kill him.
Turns businesslike and cagey after being shaken and hurt, focusing on escape demands.
Despite being dazed and bleeding, Sonny regains composure and switches to a business-like tone to negotiate demands calmly.
Initially appears bewildered and shaken, showing vulnerability and lack of immediate control over the situation.
Looks Moretti in the eye and makes kissing motions to indicate distrust, showing candidness and directness.
Negotiates the release of hostages firmly but offers to release some in exchange for his wife visiting him, showing concern for others.
Smiles and pantomimes kissing back to Moretti, indicating a playful or sincere attempt at rapport despite tension.
Negotiates with Moretti to exchange hostages for his wife and transportation, showing strategic thinking and bargaining skills.
Makes kissing motions to Moretti to indicate distrust, showing awareness of interpersonal dynamics and nonverbal communication.
Heidi defends Sonny, saying he never did anything wrong and wouldn't hurt or threaten anyone.
Yells at the kids like a madman, causing fear in Heidi.
Heidi expresses that she has never been scared of Sonny before, indicating some underlying trust or familiarity.
His mother says the cops were always at their house and they were always fighting, suggesting a troubled and possibly volatile nature.
Heidi observes Sonny acting erratically and threateningly with a gun, yelling at kids like a madman, indicating loss of control and poor judgment.
Despite the chaos and police presence, Sonny remains physically present and active in the situation, showing some level of engagement and persistence.
Engages others in a hypothetical legal puzzle, involving Maria and Miriam in conversation.
Scatters money through the air, creating a mess that Edna has to clean up.
Pacing back and forth while posing a legal puzzle to hostages, engaging them in conversation to maintain control and buy time.
Gun lying unattended on desk while pacing, potentially a security risk showing lack of situational control.
Speaks gently to the Jesus Freak on the phone despite wanting to end the call, showing patience and tolerance.
Notices Margaret is sick and immediately inquires about the air conditioning, showing concern for others' well-being.
Paces restlessly like a caged animal, showing anxiety and lack of calm control.
Listens patiently to a long, rambling phone call despite wanting to get off, showing some social tact and patience.
Hangs up on the caller when it becomes clear the call is unhelpful, demonstrating decision-making and boundary-setting.
Notices Margaret is ill and immediately checks on the air conditioning, showing situational awareness and concern.
Reassures Sal about flying, telling him it's safe and not to worry.
Moves to check the air conditioning to possibly improve conditions for the group.
Quickly reacts to a suspicious sound by arming himself to protect the group.
Moves toward the back door to investigate the air conditioning, showing initiative and situational awareness.
Hears a suspicious scratching sound, quickly reacts by retrieving a gun and preparing it, demonstrating alertness and quick response.
Peers around wildly to locate the source of the sound, indicating some nervousness or lack of calm under pressure.
Fires a warning shot deliberately aimed high to avoid hitting anyone while protecting the group inside.
Races back to cover the group after firing, showing concern for their safety.
Gives Sal the rifle and prepares to face the crowd and police himself.
Yells aggressively at Moretti when he appears behind him.
Dashes back and forth into rear bank area, actively managing the situation inside the bank.
Gives Sal the rifle and decides to come out of the bank despite the danger.
Yells aggressively at Moretti upon coming out, showing possible loss of control or poor communication.
Expresses suspicion and hostility toward Moretti, using aggressive language and refusing to trust him.
Despite tension, shows concern for the people inside by acknowledging they are hungry.
Presses Moretti aggressively for information and demands results, showing awareness of the situation's stakes.
Expresses distrust and frustration repeatedly, but does not seem to devise a clear alternative plan or solution.
Acknowledges the logistical constraints (helicopter can't land) and insists on what he needs, showing some situational understanding.
Threatens violence impulsively, which may undermine negotiation efforts and escalate tension.
Orders pizzas, sodas, and aspirins for the hostages to keep them comfortable.
Reassures Sal that things are moving forward and tries to keep everyone calm and happy.
Takes responsibility for managing the situation and caring for both hostages and accomplices.
Orders pizzas, drinks, and aspirin to keep hostages comfortable and negotiates logistics for escape plan.
Calmly reassures Sal and communicates updates about the plan and provisions.
Takes initiative to pay for the pizza using decoy money, showing practical problem-solving.
Feels pressured and overwhelmed, repeatedly stating 'I'm workin' on it' to Mulvaney, indicating some stress and possible lack of full control.
Pays for the pizza and tells the delivery boy to keep the change.
Throws wads of stolen money into the crowd, causing chaos and fights.
Throws money into the crowd to create a distraction, causing chaos among cops and civilians.
Laughs at the ensuing chaos and uses it to his advantage by re-entering the bank with food.
Puts down food in front of Mulvaney and offers it to him first, expressing concern about its safety.
Puts down food in front of Mulvaney and offers to let Mulvaney eat first, showing caution about possible tampering.
Encourages Sylvia not to start smoking, expressing concern for her health and purity.
Gives Sal a gun and informs him that his wife is being brought in, showing trust and concern for others' involvement.
Responds alertly and cooperatively to Moretti's call about his wife, indicating sincerity and emotional connection.
Responds alertly to Moretti's call about his wife being brought in, immediately takes action by arming Sal and exiting the bank to address the situation.
Continues with 'Manual of Arms' business with rifle calmly while Mulvaney is on the phone, showing focus and preparedness.
Greets Leon warmly and repeatedly wishes him a happy birthday despite Leon not responding and eventually fainting.
Dashes back into the bank after seeing Leon faint, showing concern and urgency.
Greets Leon enthusiastically and tries to engage him despite the chaotic situation.
Yells repeatedly to Leon who is disoriented and eventually faints, showing limited effectiveness in communication.
Dashes back into the bank quickly after Leon faints, indicating responsiveness and urgency.
Wants to use a phone urgently to contact Moretti and check on Leon's condition, showing concern.
Realizes all phones are in use and quickly rushes to find an available phone to make an important call.
Attempts to speak to Moretti to get information and coordinate, showing initiative and communication skills.
Shows concern and urgency in his questions about Leon's condition, indicating situational awareness.
Pays his parents' rent despite their troubled relationship, lets their issues slide off his back.
Wants to help Leon get money for a sex change operation despite financial difficulties.
Becomes frantic and flies into rages due to stress and financial demands.
Shows deep concern for Leon's well-being and tries to support him emotionally and financially despite his own difficulties.
Is under great strain and becomes frantic and enraged due to financial and emotional pressures.
Visits Leon in the hospital and shows a simple, sincere reaction ('Wow!') to his suicide attempt.
Hangs up the phone when Moretti tries to get Leon to talk to him during the bank robbery.
Hangs up the phone when Moretti tries to negotiate, avoiding communication.
Initiates a bank robbery to get money for an operation, showing some planning and motivation.
Tries to reassure Sal by telling him to ignore the media's focus on their sexuality, showing tolerance and acceptance of the situation.
Paces nervously and seems unable to control the narrative or calm others, indicating stress but also a sincere concern for the group.
Rushes to a nearby phone to try to reach Moretti when the lights go out, showing concern and initiative.
Steps out into a dangerous, dark street despite the threat, indicating courage but also recklessness.
Rushes to a nearby phone to try to reach Moretti despite the blackout.
Steps out into a dark, dangerous street with limited visibility and threatening armed cops, responding with bluster rather than caution.
Warns Sal about the FBI confrontation he is about to have.
Sarcastically accuses Sheldon of doing favors all night.
Insists on keeping one hostage (Leon) for negotiation.
Acknowledges the hostages are keeping him alive.
Steps out into the street to confront the FBI agent Sheldon, attempts to negotiate terms calmly and assertively.
Sarcastically challenges Sheldon about favors, showing confidence but possibly undermining negotiation.
Attempts to control the situation by demanding lights and air conditioning be turned back on.
Fails to locate Moretti when looking for him, indicating a possible lapse in situational awareness.
Negotiates a plan to exchange hostages at the airport, showing strategic thinking and willingness to cooperate.
Insists on talking to Leon and negotiating terms with Sheldon, demonstrating some control and tactical communication.
Grins and playfully performs a pat-down search on Sheldon, entertaining the crowd and showing a moment of lightheartedness.
Engages in a candid exchange with Sheldon about killing him, expressing a desire for personal hatred rather than a cold job, showing sincerity.
Orders the group not to give their real names to protect them, showing concern and protectiveness.
Executes a very professional-looking pat-down search on Sheldon with showmanship, maintaining control and calm.
Insists Sheldon walk in backwards to maintain control and safety during entry.
Gives clear orders to the hostages to not give their real names, showing tactical awareness.
Yells an order to protect hostages by instructing them not to give their real names, showing concern for their safety.
Covers Sheldon closely as he moves among hostages, indicating protective behavior.
Listens to Sal's concerns about being labeled, showing some tolerance and attentiveness.
Grabs Sheldon as he tries to leave, indicating a desire to maintain control and possibly protect the situation.
Handles himself well under pressure, preventing chaos and panic during the hostage situation.
Relies on Sheldon to handle Sal, indicating some delegation or possible lack of control over all aspects.
Shows concern for Mulvaney's health, asks if he is okay, and worries about the pizza being poisoned.
Restless and hyperactive, possibly indicating guilt or anxiety, but does not lash out or blame others.
Grabs Sheldon to stop him from leaving, showing assertiveness and control in a tense situation.
Appears restless and hyperactive, possibly indicating a guilty conscience and lack of calm under pressure.
Engages in conversation about arrangements and the TV, showing some situational awareness.
Notices Mulvaney fainting and immediately asks if he is okay, showing attentiveness to surroundings.
Jumps to the conclusion that the pizza was poisoned without full information, showing impulsiveness.
Shows concern for the diabetic manager's health, calls urgently for a doctor, and facilitates medical help.
Frisks a man approaching with a doctor's bag to ensure safety before allowing entry.
Engages in a caring and gentle phone conversation with Leon, expressing genuine concern for his wellbeing.
Recognizes the manager's diabetic condition and quickly calls for a doctor, showing awareness and prompt action.
Frisks a man who approaches with a doctor's bag to ensure no weapons are brought in, demonstrating caution and control.
Hustles the doctor inside to attend to the manager, coordinating medical help efficiently.
Rushes repeatedly between inside and outside the bank, managing multiple tasks under pressure.
Engages in a phone conversation with Leon, showing some concern but appears somewhat distracted or uncertain in responses.
Responds to Leon's serious concerns with chuckling and evasive remarks, avoiding deeper engagement.
Admits uncertainty about his actions ('I don't know what I'm doing').
Dismisses Leon's emotional appeal and serious reflections ('Now don't give me that deep shit').
Responds vaguely and evasively to Leon's serious concerns, showing uncertainty and lack of clear direction.
Admits 'I don't know what I'm doing' when confronted about threatening someone with a gun, indicating confusion and lack of control.
Expresses frustration but tries to communicate honestly with Leon about his pressures and decisions.
Takes full responsibility for robbing the bank without blaming others.
Shows a desire to 'square away' his accounts with Leon, indicating a wish for closure and sincerity.
Responds to Leon's despair with some impatience and defensiveness.
Admits to taking full responsibility for robbing the bank without blaming others.
Expresses uncertainty and inability to respond effectively to Leon's emotional statements.
Shows awareness of the gravity of his situation and attempts to 'square away' his accounts with life.
Offers Leon the freedom to join him on a risky escape plan, emphasizing Leon's choice and autonomy.
Expresses resignation about his fate but still tries to maintain hope and include others.
Uses coarse language and shows a reckless attitude about the situation.
Plans to escape by hijacking a jet and flying out of the situation, showing determination and a clear goal.
Admits uncertainty about the destination (Algeria) and gives a trivial reason for going there (Howard Johnson's), indicating lack of thorough planning.
Confidently invites Leon to join him, showing leadership and decisiveness.
Acknowledges being 'warped' and crazy, which may reflect self-awareness but also suggests instability.
Laughs and jokes with Leon, showing camaraderie.
Expresses responsibility for others' lives and determination to not give up.
Defends Leon against false accusations, calling them crazy and bullshit.
Acknowledges responsibility for lives involved and commits to getting out of the mess the best way he knows, emphasizing not giving up.
Dismisses concerns about Leon being seen as an accomplice with confident denial and rationalization.
Engages in banter about locations (Denmark, Sweden, Wyoming) without clear strategic purpose, showing some lack of seriousness or focus.
Shows concern for Leon's situation and pressures for communication with the police to protect him.
Expresses anger and frustration towards Leon for not informing him about the phone call, but still tries to manage the situation calmly afterward.
Questions Leon repeatedly and angrily about who is on the phone, showing frustration but attempting to control the situation.
Fails to get clear information from Leon and reacts emotionally rather than strategically.
Calms down and tries to reason with Leon after the outburst, indicating some level of control and adaptability.
Encourages Leon about his hospital stay and operation, shows concern for his well-being.
Says goodbye to Leon in a sincere, somewhat lighthearted manner, indicating friendly and genuine interaction.
Requests to talk to his wife and say goodbye to his kids, showing emotional openness and care for family.
Engages in a calm, supportive conversation with Leon, showing emotional intelligence and patience.
Attempts to contact his wife to say goodbye, indicating awareness of the gravity of the situation and taking initiative.
Expresses uncertainty verbally ('I don't know what to say to ya!'), showing some hesitation or lack of clear direction.
Calls his wife to say goodbye and asks about the kids, showing concern for family despite crisis.
Expresses anguish and vulnerability openly during the phone call.
Attempts to call his wife to say goodbye, showing emotional vulnerability but also a desire to connect and manage the situation.
Expresses anguish and despair openly, indicating emotional turmoil and lack of calm control.
Tells Heidi to shut up harshly and yells at her.
Sits dispiritedly listening to Heidi's complaints, reflecting on the waste of living with people like her.
Gently tells Heidi not to call herself fat.
Weakly asks Heidi why she didn't come down to see him.
Reassures Heidi that the police are after him, not her.
Drops the phone on the hook, ignoring Heidi's ongoing talk.
Yells at Heidi to shut up and listen, showing frustration but attempting to assert control.
Sits dispiritedly listening to Heidi's complaints, reflecting on the wasted life with people like her, showing introspection but passivity.
Responds weakly to Heidi's question about why she didn't come down, indicating lack of confidence or decisiveness.
Drops the phone on the hook while Heidi continues talking, indicating avoidance and failure to engage effectively.
Shows concern for Mulvaney's health, tries to help him despite resistance.
Gets frustrated and somewhat confrontational when Mulvaney resists help.
